Practical, transparent standards that prioritize stewardship and operational efficiency can bridge concerns across industry, consumers, and regulators.
statements.606: Treat personal data like a curated canvas: gather only what’s needed, label and explain each use in plain language, and guard it with rigorous security so technology enhances life without eroding dignity. Combine meaningful user controls, privacy-by-design, independent oversight, and clear remedies for misuse to balance creative innovation with accountable protection for vulnerable people.
statements.612: A lifetime of careful listening and tending a treasured collection argues that tech companies must steward personal data with restraint: collect only what is necessary, secure it rigorously, and explain uses in plain, accessible language. Meaningful consent, simple user controls, independent oversight, and fair remedies can balance innovation with protection for families and vulnerable people, building the practical trust that allows technology to serve communities without exploiting them.
statements.742: Tech companies must steward user data as a public trust—collecting only what is necessary, securing it with strong, industry-leading safeguards, and explaining uses in plain, accessible language so families and individuals can make informed choices. Practical, enforceable standards—privacy-by-design, data minimization, meaningful consent, independent audits, and clear remedies, with special protections for children and other vulnerable users—can preserve innovation while building the predictable accountability communities need to trust digital services.
statements.560: User data must be treated as a trust: collect only what is necessary, secure it rigorously, and explain practices in plain language so families can make informed choices and children receive extra protections. Practical, proportionate rules—meaningful consent, easy-to-use controls, independent audits, and clear remedies for misuse—can hold companies accountable while leaving room for responsible innovation that serves the public good.
statements.445: Protecting families and everyday users requires tech companies to practice simple, common-sense stewardship: collect only what’s needed, secure it well, and explain uses in plain language so busy households can make informed choices. Practical safeguards—strong security, meaningful consent and controls, independent audits, and targeted regulation that protects children while preserving useful services—balance privacy with the real-world needs of businesses and communities.
statements.395: Experience caring for patients and families shows that personal data—especially health and children's information—deserves the same disciplined stewardship as clinical records: collect only what is necessary, secure it rigorously, and explain uses in plain language. Practical privacy-by-design practices, clear consent and accessible controls, independent oversight, and proportionate remedies can protect dignity and safety while allowing responsible innovation to deliver valuable services.
statements.448: Tech companies should treat user data as a public trust, limiting collection to what is necessary, securing systems with proven practices, and offering clear, plain-language controls so families and communities can make informed choices. Balanced, enforceable standards—privacy-by-design, independent audits, meaningful remedies, and special protections for children—alongside reasonable allowances for legitimate public‑safety and innovation needs will protect individual dignity while keeping useful services available.
statements.704: Grounded in years of hands-on patient care and community engagement, tech firms should steward user data with the same practical respect and transparency expected in face-to-face services—collect only what is necessary, secure it robustly, and explain uses in plain language so people and families can make informed choices. Meaningful, easy-to-use controls, extra protections for children and sensitive health information, independent oversight, and clear avenues for redress can balance innovation with dignity and public trust, allowing useful services to thrive without treating personal information as a commodity.
statements.350: Tech companies should treat user data as entrusted information, collecting only what is essential, securing it well, and explaining uses in plain, customer-friendly language so families and everyday users can make informed choices. Practical safeguards—strong default privacy settings, easy-to-use controls, independent oversight, and clear remedies for misuse—can protect vulnerable people, uphold trust, and allow responsible innovation to continue.
statements.613: User data should be treated as a public trust and a matter of personal dignity—collected only when necessary, secured rigorously, and explained in plain, language‑accessible terms so people balancing work, daily life, and creative pursuits can understand and control how their information is used. Practical safeguards—privacy‑by‑design, meaningful consent and opt‑outs, independent oversight, and clear remedies—let responsible innovation flourish while protecting children, vulnerable communities, and basic rights.
